Electromagnetically induced transparency of an
interacting cold Rydberg ensemble
K J Weatherill, J D Pritchard, M G Bason, A K Mohapatra
and C S Adams
Department of Physics, Durham University, Rochester Building, South Road,
Durham DH1 3LE, UK
E-mail: k.j.weatherill@durham.ac.uk
Abstract. We study electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT) of a weakly
interacting cold Rydberg gas. We show that for Rydberg states with principal quantum
numbers in the range n = 19−26, the onset of interactions is manifest as a depopulation
of the Rydberg state. In the limit of a weak probe where the depopulation effect is
negligible, we observe no evidence of interaction induced decoherence and obtain a
narrow Rydberg dark resonance with a linewidth of <600 kHz.
PACS numbers: 03.67.Lx, 32.80.Rm, 42.50.Gy
Ensembles of Rydberg atoms display fascinating many-body behavior due to their
strong interactions [1]. These interactions lead to interesting cooperative effects such
as superradiance [2, 3, 4] and dipole blockade [5, 6, 7, 8], which may provide the basis
for applications such as single–photon sources [9] and quantum gates [10, 11, 12]. For
quantum information applications one is interested in the coherent evolution of the
ensemble. Coherent excitation of Rydberg states has been achieved using adiabatic
passage [13, 14]. Rabi oscillations between ground and Rydberg states with dipole–
dipole interactions have been observed [15, 16]. Also, the coherence of a Rydberg
ensemble has been measured directly using a spin echo technique [17]. In most
experiments on ultracold Rydberg gases, the Rydberg atoms are detected indirectly
following field ionization and subsequent detection of electrons (or ions) using a micro
channel plate (MCP). However, recently we demonstrated non-destructive optical
detection of Rydberg states in room temperature Rb vapor [18, 19] using EIT [20, 21].
The same technique was subsequently used to detect Rydberg states in a Sr atomic
beam [22]. Rydberg EIT has number of potential applications, for example, a Rydberg
EIT medium displays a giant dc electro—optic effect many orders of magnitude larger
than other systems [23] enabling precision electrometry, and Rydberg EIT could be
used to a realize a photonic phase gate [24]. However, exactly how interaction effects
are manifest in Rydberg EIT, e.g. as a dipole-dipole induced level shift, decoherence or
loss is unknown.
2Figure 1. (Color online) (a) Schematic of the experimental setup. A strong coupling
beam (blue) stabilized to the 5p 2P3/2 → nD (or nS) transition counter–propagates a
weak probe beam (red) through a cold sample of 85Rb released from a magneto–optical
trap (MOT). The probe scans over a range of ±20 MHz about the F = 3 → F ′ = 4
resonance in 480 µs. (b) Simplified level scheme, Rabi frequencies and decay rates used
to model the Rydberg EIT. Levels |4〉 represent states other than state |2〉 to which
the Rydberg state |3〉 can decay.
In this work we demonstrate EIT involving Rydberg states in an ultra–cold atomic
sample. We show that interactions between Rydberg atoms lead to a rapid depopulation
of the Rydberg state, and that the EIT spectra are extremely sensitive to small changes
in the interaction strength. For example, changing the principal quantum number of
the Rydberg state from n to n + 1 produces a significant change in the EIT spectrum.
By using a weak probe, where the probability of populating the Rydberg state is low,
we can eliminate this depopulation effect and obtain narrow Rydberg dark resonances
with a linewidth of < 600 kHz.
The experimental setup and simplified level scheme are shown in figure 1 (a) and
(b) respectively. A probe and coupling beam are combined using dichroic mirrors and
counter–propagate through a cloud of laser–cooled 85Rb atoms. The polarization of
the beams are chosen to maximize transition strengths (σ+–σ+). The probe beam is
derived from a diode laser at 780.24 nm stabilized to the |1〉 → |2〉, 5s 2S1/2(F = 3)
→ 5p 2P3/2 (F ′ = 4) transition using polarization spectroscopy [25]. The frequency is
controlled using two successive acousto-optic modulators (AOMs). The beam is then
coupled into an optical fiber, the output of which is collimated and passed through
an aperture resulting in a beam of almost uniform intensity and radius of 0.75 mm.
The coupling beam is derived from a commercial frequency doubled diode laser system
(Toptica TA-SHG) at λ=483–487 nm resonant with the |2〉 → |3〉, 5p 2P3/2 (F ′ = 4) →
nd 2D5/2 (or ns
2S1/2) (F
′′) transition and passed through an optical fiber. The beam
has a 1/e2 radius of 0.8 mm and power up to 97 mW. The frequency of the coupling laser
is stabilized using a Rydberg EIT signal produced in a magnetically shielded rubidium
3vapor cell at room temperature [26].
We load approximately 108 atoms in a magneto–optical trap (MOT) in 5 s.
A subsequent 10 ms optical molasses phase cools the atoms to a temperature of
approximately 20 µK and density 1010 cm−3, following which the cooling light is
extinguished. An optical pumping pulse of variable duration prepares the atoms in the
F = 3,mF = 3 state. After 3 ms free expansion the coupling and probe beams are turned
on and the frequency of the probe is swept across the D2 F = 3 → F ′ = 4 transition.
The sweep covers ± 20 MHz on either side of the resonance in 480 µs. Absorption
measurements show that there is negligible density decrease over the duration of the
scan and negligible optical pumping into the lower (F = 2) hyperfine ground state for
the probe powers of interest. The probe beam is incident on a fast photodiode which
records the transmission through the sample. This technique of measuring the narrow
linewidth EIT spectra from a cold atomic sample within a single experimental cycle offers
a faster repetition rate than ionization experiments. In addition Rydberg EIT provides
a continuous probe of the Rydberg energy level with a bandwidth limited by the larger
of the linewidth of the intermediate state or the two–photon Rabi frequency [23]. A
disadvantage of Rydberg EIT is that one only obtains information about the population
in the ground state and the coupled Rydberg state. In contrast, state-selective field
ionisation techniques where the population in other Rydberg states can be detected is
better suited to studying population transfer processes.
In figure 2 we show a series of EIT spectra for a fixed probe power of 3.6 µW
corresponding to 0.13 Isat, where Isat is the saturation intensity on the |1〉 → |2〉
transition. The absorption data has been corrected for the measured change in probe
intensity through the optical fiber as a function of AOM frequency. The effect of varying
the cloud density, ρ, and principal quantum number, n, are shown in figures 2 (a) and
(b), respectively. The density, ρ, is changed by heating the atom cloud (of initial density
ρ0) with the probe beam prior to the EIT scan. In figure 2 (b) the power of the coupling
laser is varied to make the coupling Rabi frequency the same for each scan. For low ρ or
low n a characteristic EIT spectrum is observed with a slight asymmetry. As ρ or n are
increased this asymmetry becomes more pronounced until the transparency peak is lost
completely. The lineshape for n > 22 does not change dramatically with n as illustrated
by the similarity to the n = 26 and n = 22 data sets, the front curves in figure 2 (a) and
(b), respectively. The data presented in figure 2 is suggestive of a density–dependent
depopulation of the Rydberg state.
By varying the probe power we can change the fractional probability that an atom
is excited to the Rydberg state. In figure 3 we show the transmission spectrum for the
|3〉=19d state for two probe powers of 450 nW (0.016 Isat) and 3.6 µW (0.13 Isat). In
this case we present double scans where the probe laser detuning is first increased and
then decreased through the resonance in a total time of 960 µs. We observe that at the
higher probe power there is significantly less absorption on the second scan than the first
indicating that atoms excited to the Rydberg state are being lost from the EIT system.
For these parameters only a small fraction of the population, a few percent, is transferred
4Figure 2. (Color online) (a) Transmission of a 3.6 µW probe beam as a function of
probe laser detuning for the 85Rb |1〉 → |2〉 → |3〉 = 26d system for varying atomic
density. Constant coupling beam power of 97 mW (b) EIT spectra for n=19–22. The
Rabi frequency of the |2〉 → |3〉 transition is kept the same for each state varying from
61 mW for n = 19 to 74 mW for n = 22. In both plots the onset of density–dependent
behavior is evident in the emergence of an EIT lineshape at lower values of n and ρ
into and out of the Rydberg state for a time of order 10 µs. However, to model the
data (see next paragraph) we find that >70% of the atoms are lost from the 3-level EIT
system. This substantial loss cannot be explained by spontaneous decay from Rydberg
state (since the spontaneous lifetime is also of order ∼10 µs [27] and decreases with larger
n) or by optical pumping to the lower hyperfine state. We therefore deduce that there
is an interaction induced loss from the system happening on a much faster time scale
than the Rydberg state lifetime. In addition, with the available frequency resolution we
are unable to resolve any dipole-dipole induced shift which is not unexpected for the
Rydberg density and principal quantum numbers accessible in the current study.

Although there is a number of possible mechanisms for the loss of Rydberg atoms
from the system, eg. dipole-dipole energy transfer [28], the most likely conjecture for
low n states is that the decay out of the EIT system is driven by superradiant decay of
the Rydberg state to nearby f and p states. Observation of similar loss dynamics from
nearby s states support this supposition as the dipole–dipole interactions are repulsive
(attractive) for s (d) states [29]. The potential importance of superradiance in frozen
6Rydberg gases particularly involving lower n states has been highlighted in recent work
[4, 30]. In general superradiance is more significant for low n as the decay rate to nearby
Rydberg levels scales as 1/n5, however there is also a geometrical effect which depends
on the wavelength of the superradiant transition, λs, in comparison to the size of the
cloud, D [30]. For the range of n studied in this work (n = 19 to 26) λs is less than D
for decay to the closest f states i.e. the atoms are spatially spread over a range greater
than the transition wavelength such that cooperative effects are small. However, λs is
of order or greater than D for decay to the closest p states i.e. all atoms are within
one wavelength and the emission rate is greatly enhanced. In this critical region the
geometric cooperativity parameter [30] increases rapidly with increasing n which could
explain the dramatic evolution of EIT spectra shown in figure 2 (b). The dependence of
superradiance on λs and D is supported by the similarity of figure 2 (a) and (b) where
for both data sets the value of λsD varies by a factor of 1.6 between the front and back
trace [31]. Our simple non–linear optical Bloch equation model begins to fail for larger
n. For example, for the high density 26d trace shown in figure 2 (a) no evidence of
EIT is observable whereas the model predicts a pronounced shoulder after the laser has
passed through the two–photon resonance. We also note that one can obtain a better
fit to the high density and higher n data by coupling the optical Bloch equations to
an equation describing the superradiance field energy density. This model reproduces
the lineshapes observed in the experiment, in particular the complete loss of the EIT
shoulder, however as the time scale of the decay of the superradiance field is not known,
this model does not provide useful quantitative information. The current experimental
arrangement precludes the unambiguous identification of the depopulation mechanism
since neither ionized atoms or superradiant emissions (with wavelength in the range
of 1 mm) can be detected directly. Further evidence could be obtained by performing
experiments for a larger range of n, however, for the current geometry (approximately
spherical excitation volume with diameter 1 mm) we are limited to n . 26 by the
available coupling laser power (80 mW).
Of more interest to applications in non-linear optics [23], high resolution
spectroscopy and electrometry is the weak probe limit where the population of the
Rydberg state is small. This limit highlights the power of EIT as a non-destructive
continuous probe of Rydberg states. Figure 4 shows the transmission spectrum for
the |3〉=26d state using a low probe power of 200 nW (0.007 Isat). In this case no
loss or additional decoherence of the Rydberg state is observed between the forward
and back scan. We obtain a typical EIT linewidth of 600 kHz. The EIT linewidth is
made up of two terms; a term proportional to the coupling Rabi frequency squared, Ω232
(i.e. the Autler–Townes splitting), and a term corresponding to the coherence between
the ground state and the Rydberg state, γ31. This coherence term is the sum of the
combined laser linewidth and interaction dependent dephasing mechanisms. From the
fit we obtain Ω32/2pi = 1.8±0.3 MHz and γ31 = 100±20 kHz, i.e. for our parameters the
linewidth is dominated by the Autler-Townes term. We observe no change in γ31 over
the range n = 19 to n = 26 showing that the combined laser linewidth dominates over
7any interaction induced dephasing of the Rydberg state. Note that such long coherence
times cannot be observed in non–Rydberg cascade EIT due to the short lifetime of
the upper state. The frequency resolution obtained using this method is comparable
to the best obtained on single atoms [15] and considerably better than the resolution
obtained for other ensembles experiments [16, 32, 33], where interaction effects tend to
broaden the linewidth to greater than one MHz. This narrow resonance demonstrates
a significant advantage of EIT for precision spectroscopy or electrometry, i.e. that
the observed transparency is sensitive to the Rydberg energy level without transferring
significant population into it. From the OBE model we find that the probability for an
atom to be in the Rydberg state to be ∼0.15% giving ρ < 107 cm−3 which corresponds
to a total Rydberg population of less than 104 atoms.

In conclusion, we have shown that EIT is a useful technique to probe the properties
of interacting Rydberg ensembles. We find that for principal quantum numbers in the
range n = 19−26, interaction effects are manifest as a rapid depopulation of the Rydberg
state. This density dependent loss can be modeled heuristically using non–linear optical
Bloch equations. The character of the loss is similar for changes in either the atomic
density or the principal quantum n of the Rydberg state, suggesting a superradiant decay
mechanism. In the limit of weak probe power, where the depopulation effect is negligible
we observe no evidence of interaction induced decoherence and the linewidth is limited
by the Autler–Townes splitting. In this limit EIT provides a sensitive non–destructive
probe of cold Rydberg ensembles. In contrast to conventional spectroscopy, Rydberg
EIT allows one to probe Rydberg energy levels continuously without significant Rydberg
population thereby interaction induced line broadening mechanisms can be controlled
allowing high–resolution spectroscopy of Rydberg states. In future work we will focus
8on extending the range of Rydberg EIT to smaller excitation volumes and states with
higher principal quantum numbers, where dipole-dipole induced energy level shift are
expected to dominate over superradiant decay.
